I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  During the 2006 Country Partnership Strategy Confirmation Mission, the Government 
requested ADB’s continuing assistance for gas sector development activities. Subsequently, 
ADB included a Gas Sector Development Program PPTA for 2007 and a follow-up loan in the 
2008 business plan.1 A Fact Finding Mission (Mission) of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) 
visited Bangladesh from 10 to 15 April 2007 to evaluate the readiness for project preparatory 
technical assistance (PPTA) for the proposed Bangladesh Gas Sector Development Program 
(the Program).2 The preliminary project design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
  
II.  ISSUES 
2.  Non-commercial  energy,  primarily  biomass,  accounts  for  almost  two-thirds  of  total 
energy consumption in Bangladesh. Natural gas accounts for about 70% of commercial energy. 
Natural gas will provide most of the current and future commercial energy requirements, and the 
gas market needs to be expanded to optimize the use of natural gas resources and support 
economic development. Although Bangladesh has been producing natural gas for over three 
decades, most of its major fields are underdeveloped and have not been properly delineated. 
There are widely varying assessments of the country’s potential natural gas resources. Total 
proven recoverable gas reserves in Bangladesh from 23 fields (18 in the public and 5 in the 
private sector) are estimated at 20.5 trillion cubic feet (TCF), of which 6.8 TCF has so far been 
consumed. The current net recoverable reserves stand at 13.7 TCF, with potentially substantial 
underdeveloped and/or undiscovered natural gas reserves. 
 
3.  Bangladesh Oil, Gas and Minerals Corporation (Petrobangla) coordinates the gas sector 
activities in the country while the Energy and Mineral Resources Division (EMRD) of the Ministry 
of  Power,  Energy,  and  Mineral  Resources  (MPEMR)  provides  the  overall  policy  direction. 
Petrobangla carries out its gas business through nine operating companies.3 Performance in 
the gas sector has been below its potential because of low gas extraction, lack of internal 
investment, and limited use of the domestic market. Also, the price of natural gas in Bangladesh 
remains low compared with neighboring countries. The underpricing of domestic gas use leads 
to a high opportunity cost in terms of foregone resources that could have been mobilized to 
support  investment  within  and  outside  the  sector,  especially  given  the  country’s  massive 
development financing needs. 
 
4.  The Government of Bangladesh (the Government) recognizes the need to introduce 
gradual  reforms  aimed  at  commercializing  the  sector  and  placing  some  distance  between 
operations, regulations and policy making. Although individual, independent companies have 
been established (the separate nine operating companies mentioned earlier), there has been

limited delegation of authority from the Government to the management of these sector entities, 
and from the management to the staff.  
   
5.  ADB has been involved in the gas sector intermittently over the last 25 years, and 
provided eight loans totaling $446 million. As in other countries, the role of ADB has evolved 
from a provider of funds for individual products to a more proactive and comprehensive role 
involving technical advice for project preparation and policy advice in implementing sector 
reforms. Currently, there are two active gas sector loans and one advisory technical assistance 
(TA) project. The Dhaka Clean Fuel Project is almost completed,4 while the Gas Transmission 
and Development Project was declared effective 1 year after loan approval, with implementation 
now progressing well.5 ADB also provided advisory TA to assess the role of the private sector in 
energy sector development, with a final tripartite workshop held on 24 April 2007.6  
 
6.    Several major initiatives were taken under the Gas Transmission and Development 
Project (GTDP), including the development of the Gas Sector Reform Roadmap (GSRR). The 
GSRR includes (i) a program and a strategy for development of old and new gas production 
fields, (ii) expansion of gas transmission and distribution pipelines, (iii) a mechanism for gas 
sector policy formulation and introduction of required regulatory instruments, (iv) strengthening of 
corporate and financial governance of gas sector companies, (v) private sector participation, (vi) 
price reforms, and (vii) system loss reduction plans. These activities are to be undertaken in 
parallel with the implementation of the GTDP.  
 
7.    The Government recognizes that while an improved gas sector has the potential to 
contribute significantly to the development of the economy, it would have to be effectively 
managed to maximize its role in poverty reduction and ensure an equitable distribution of 
benefits. The Government is actively following the Gas Sector Master Plan prepared in 2006 by 
the Government with assistance from the World Bank.7 This plan outlines a vision for gas sector 
restructuring, ownership, private sector participation, and regulation. Progress in implementing 
policy  reforms  can  be  improved  significantly,  however,  and  it  is  important  to  maintain  the 
momentum created by previous assistance and progress. Several elements stand out as key 
areas for focus and improvement.  
 
8.    One critical element is security of the gas supply. Numerous analyses have shown a 
positive  relation  between  gas  consumption  and  increases  in  gross  domestic  product  in 
Bangladesh. At the same time, the country’s rate of gas consumption is alarmingly close to its 
production and delivery capabilities. The certain and probable gas reserves available today will 
support the country’s desired level of economic growth until only 2011 (or 2018 at most); a key 
challenge is to assure, though additional exploration, development and production activities, the 
continued availability of reliable gas supplies. The challenge will be to create an environment that 
will  provide  funding  to  the  domestic  operating  companies  for  such  activities,  and  to  attract 
investment from experienced foreign companies. 
 
9.    This will require focusing on another priority element, the design and implementation of 
competitive and equitable pricing policies. The sector needs to retain enough funds to not only 
properly maintain the system but also to carry out the exploration, development and production

functions needed to ensure security of the supply. It is well known that proper pricing prevents 
wasteful resource use. At present, gas pricing in Bangladesh is based on a complex system of 
cross-subsidies, and certain elements within the domestic economy may be unable to support gas 
price increases. Affordability should be maintained through development of subsidies that can be 
applied directly to the targeted end-consumers, without involving the entire gas sector in such 
social activities. 
 
10.    Another priority element in gas sector reform is that system losses need to be reduced to 
levels consistent with a properly maintained and operated system. Beyond technical solutions 
such as improved maintenance to reduce leaks, institutional solutions and good governance in the 
gas sector operating companies are required to ultimately reduce losses. Transparency with 
respect to transmission quantities, delivery to individual off-take points, and collections associated 
with those points must be enhanced through improved book keeping, metering and collection 
procedures. Regional management teams must be given incentives to lower losses and increase 
profits, and be given adequate oversight powers. 
 
11.    Proper coordination between the power and gas sectors is crucial, as the power sector is 
the largest consumer of gas (at present more than 90% of the country’s power is generated with 
gas). As both sectors are capital intensive, efficient, least-cost investment solutions for both 
sectors cannot occur without close coordination. Proper planning of the gas transmission and 
distribution network requires knowledge of the long-term plans of the power sector with respect to 
capacity addition (and the location of added capacity); likewise, planning for future gas-fired power 
generation plants must take into account the constraints of and future investment plans for the gas 
sector.   
 
12.   Institutional capacity development in policy making, monitoring and system and investment 
planning is another key element of gas sector viability, and is needed to ensure progress in the 
other  key  elements  mentioned  above.  Human  resource  development  to  promote  adequate 
continuity  of  trained  personnel  throughout  Petrobangla  and  its  nine  gas  sector  operating 
companies is an important need. Institutional capacity development should also focus on the 
Bangladesh Energy Regulatory Commission (BERC), to facilitate the objective of separating the 
gas sector’s policy-making, regulatory and operational functions. It is thus important to ensure 
adequate institutional capacity at BERC from the outset, as adequate gas sector governance 
depends on a viable and empowered regulator with the skills to carry out audit functions and 
employ objective criteria in regulating the sector. A key lesson from past interventions is that 
sector reforms take time, and that a blend of policy promotion and investment assistance can 
yield the most progress.  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
13.  The purpose of the TA is to help the Government prepare a new gas sector development 
program to build on the progress from the ongoing project. The program will include (i) a policy 
agenda, (ii) priority investments, and (iii) an institutional capacity development component for 
the gas sector. The Government has proposed several investments for ADB financing under the 
ensuing Program. These have been selected from the Gas Sector Master Plan subprojects. The 
policy component will include an agenda for gas sector development and necessary budgetary 
support.

4   
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
14.  The TA will be provided in two stages, with the first component focusing on policy and 
institutional capacity development. Activities include reviewing the sector road map and gas 
sector  master  plan,  and  identifying  additional  institutional  capacity  development  needs  for 
Petrobangla,  its  operating  companies,  and  relevant  government  agencies.  Findings  will  be 
combined into a coherent policy matrix. The second component focuses on investment, and will 
involve (i) reviewing project proposals and other documents to define the scope of the different 
components for financing under the ensuing program; (ii) making a technical review of the 
proposals to confirm their suitability and soundness and preparing implementation schedules for 
the selected components; and (iii) undertaking financial and economic, environmental, social, 
poverty reduction, and institutional analyses of the investment feasibility studies prepared by the 
Government. The ensuing program activities are not expected to be located in or pass through 
areas of significant settlement or use by indigenous people. However, some of the proposed 
investment components consist of construction of gas pipelines and will involve land acquisition 
and potentially some resettlement. Proper resettlement plans will be developed in accordance 
with ADB guidelines. 
 
15.  Key activities include the following. 
 
(i)  Preparing a report that analyzes the potential for gas sector development.  
(ii)  Preparing a report that assesses policy and non-policy barriers to improving gas 
sector development.  
(iii)  Identifying a policy matrix for the promotion of institutional capacity development in 
the gas sector.  
(iv)  Preparing an internal report that analyzes the potential for economic growth and 
social development in program areas, with particular reference to expanding natural 
gas supply and distribution.  
(v)  Developing an investment package that identifies relevant subprojects.  
(vi)  Performing detailed financial, economic, environmental, social, poverty reduction, 
and institutional analyses of the identified subprojects, including resettlement plans 
as necessary.  
(vii)  Reviewing cost estimates, financing plans and procurement packages.   
(viii)  Preparing an estimate of potential reductions in greenhouse gas emissions from the 
subprojects. 
(ix)  Reviewing and assisting in finalizing procurement packages, bid documents, terms of 
reference,  expertise  requirements,  and  person-month  estimates  for  consulting 
services in support of the project design work and implementation of the ensuing 
loan. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
16.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $720,000 equivalent. ADB will finance $575,000 
equivalent.  The TA will be financed on a grant basis by the Japan Special Fund, funded by the 
Government of Japan. The Government will finance the remaining $145,000 equivalent of local 
currency  costs  through  in-kind  contributions,  including  office  accommodation  and  facilities, 
counterpart staff, data and other information. The detailed cost estimates and financing plan are 
presented in Appendix 3. The Government has been informed that approval of the TA does not 
commit ADB to finance any ensuing program.

5
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
17.  The Executing Agency (EA) for the TA will be Petrobangla, which will appoint a senior 
staff member as the project director. The TA mainly will finance the services of international and 
national consultants. The TA will be carried out over a 5-month period by an internationally 
recognized consulting firm in association with national consultants. The TA will commence in 
September 2007 and will be completed by January 2008. The consultants for the TA will be 
recruited by ADB on the basis of submission of simplified technical proposals in accordance 
with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2007, as amended from time to time) and 
using the quality- and cost-based selection procedure. The national consultants, who will be 
associated with the international consultants, will also be engaged by ADB in accordance with 
ADB’s  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of  Consultants.  International  consultants  will  procure  the 
equipment to be financed under the TA in accordance with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines 
(2007, as amended from time to time), through direct purchase procedures with quotations from 
at least three suppliers.  A TA project management office will be established in Petrobangla and 
will  be  responsible  for  day-to-day  management  of  the  TA  and  will  coordinate  with  all 
governmental and non-government stakeholders of the proposed Program.  
 
18.  International consultants will be engaged for a total of 13 person-months, and national 
consultants for 26 person-months. The consulting team will comprise international experts in (i) 
gas sector policy development, (ii) natural gas system analysis, (iii) natural gas economics, and 
(iv)  financial  analysis.  The  national  experts  will  have  expertise  in  (i)  gas  sector  policy 
development, (ii) institutional analysis and development, (iii) environment impact assessment, 
(iv) social development assessment, (v) financial management and restructuring, (vi) power 
sector assessment, (vii) gas economics, and (viii) gas policy. The outline terms of reference for 
the consultants are in Appendix 4. 
 
19.  International (3 person-months) and national (3 person-months) gas sector development 
specialists will be recruited for policy agenda preparatory work at the earliest opportunity, and 
will therefore be recruited as individual consultants immediately after TA approval, but this will 
not affect the total scheduled consultant time (13 person-months of international and 26 person-
months of national consultants). The individually recruited consultants will be responsible for 
identifying and summarizing a gas sector policy matrix according to the gas sector reform 
agenda and GSRR. The detailed TOR can be found in Section III of Appendix 4. 
 
20.  The consultant team (i.e., the consulting firm) will submit an inception report two weeks 
after TA commencement and a draft final report four months later. The Government and ADB 
will provide comments and these will be discussed at tripartite meetings. At the end of 5 months, 
the consultants will submit the final report incorporating government and ADB comments on the 
draft final report. During the TA processing stage, the Government has fully concurred with the 
impact, outcome, implementation arrangements, cost, financing arrangements, and TOR of the 
proposed TA. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
21.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $575,000 on a grant basis to 
the  Government  of  Bangladesh  for  Preparing  the  Gas  Sector  Development  Program,  and 
hereby reports this action to the Board.

INITIAL POVERTY AND SOCIAL ANALYSIS  
 
A.  Linkages to the Country Poverty Analysis

Contribution of the sector or subsector to reduce poverty in Bangladesh: 
 
The gas sector has an excellent potential to contribute to economic development, but infrastructure facilities need to 
be expanded and managed more effectively to ensure consistent economic growth in Bangladesh. Development of the 
gas sector is also strongly connected to poverty reduction. As a clean source of energy, gas will ensure that the poor 
will benefit, as they bear a larger share of the adverse impacts of pollution and environmental degradation.  
 
Women will also benefit from having improved and more reliable access to gas, as they can reduce the considerable 
time they otherwise spend collecting fuel wood. 
 
In addition, Bangladesh’s agriculture and agro- industries will also benefit from the development of gas-based 
fertilizers. 
 
Policy reforms that would lead to private sector development in the sector will also support improvements in service 
accountability, transparency and accessibility. 
 
 
B.  Poverty Analysis   Targeting Classification: General intervention 
 
What type of poverty analysis is needed?  
 
Consultants will undertake a study to assess the impact of gas sector development on prices and tariffs. These 
impacts will be evaluated and possible mitigating measures for vulnerable customers will be considered during project 
preparatory technical assistance (PPTA) implementation. The poverty impact assessment will include an evaluation of 
the impact of the proposed Program on individuals, households, and groups in general, and the impacts on poor and 
vulnerable segments of society. The poverty impact ratio will also be estimated.  
 
Consultants will prepare social and poverty impact assessments. The social assessment will include a review of 
socioeconomic impacts of the ensuing Program, a review of land acquisition and relocation plans, the preparation of 
resettlement plans if required, and the incorporation of mitigation measures in cost estimates. 
 
 
C.  Participation Process 
 
Is there a stakeholder analysis?    Yes     No  
 
Is there a participation strategy?     Yes                   No 
 
A participation strategy will be devised during PPTA implementation. Options will be reviewed to enhance stakeholder 
participation and local ownership. Consultation will be carried out, particularly during the preparation of the Program, 
to ensure adverse impacts are minimized and mitigated. Special attention will be given assessing the needs of 
vulnerable households. Affected communities will be consulted during the design and implementation stages. 
 
 
D.  Gender Development 
  
Strategy to maximize impacts on women: 
 
The poor, women and other vulnerable groups will be carefully considered in participatory activities. Women are 
expected to benefit from a more accessible and reliable gas supply, are they mainly responsible for collecting fuel for 
their households. Their health is expected to improve through substitution of gas for other fuel sources that release 
more pollutants.

11  Appendix 4 
 
 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  International Consultants 
 
1.  The  consultant  shall  ensure  that  works  and  outputs  undertaken  in  the  course  of  the 
technical assistance (TA) are fully compliant with all relevant Asian Development Bank (ADB) 
policies and guidelines. The terms of reference (TOR) for consultants include the following.  
 
  1.  Gas Sector Development Specialist and Team Leader (4 person-months) 
 
(i)  Serve as team leader for studies to be conducted under the TA. In this capacity, the 
consultant will coordinate with other team members to develop a detailed work plan 
and implementation schedule, work with the Bangladesh Oil, Gas and Minerals 
Corporation (Petrobangla) to oversee the consulting team, and compile, edit, and 
ensure the quality of the final report.  
 
(ii)  Refine the selected proposed policy agenda (policy matrix to be developed by the 
individual consultants) and investment components to a conclusive level of detail, 
ensuring the documentation is adequate for inclusion in the final program design. 
 
(iii)  Review  the  scope,  cost  estimates,  implementation  schedule,  and  contracting 
implementation arrangements, and formulate suitable procurement packages. 
 
(iv)  Based  on  the  above  reviews  and  analysis,  and  in  coordination  with  the  other 
members of the team, recommend the necessary policy, investment, and capacity-
building measures to be addressed under the proposed Bangladesh Gas Sector 
Development Program (the Program).  
 
(v)  Prepare a final project report consisting of information needed for ADB to bring the 
investment proposal to its Board for consideration. 
 
2.  Gas Sector System Specialist (2 person-months) 
 
(i)  Review the scope, capital and operating cost estimates, implementation schedule, 
and  contracting  and  implementation  arrangements  for  the  proposed  investment 
components and the entire Program.  
 
(ii)  Review ongoing policy reforms in the power and natural gas sectors and assist in 
integrating the policy matrix into the ensuing sector development program.  
 
(iii)  Review the existing gas transmission and distribution network and plans for their 
future expansion, and evaluate the least-cost option for urgent rehabilitation work. 
 
(iv)  Prepare cost estimates for rehabilitation and new interconnection installations. 
 
  3.  Energy/Gas Economist (2 person-months) 
 
(i)  Estimate  the  economic  capital  and  operating  costs,  and  carries  out  least-cost,

C.   Individual Consultants’ Terms of Reference 
 
Two  individually  recruited  consultants  will  commence  their  work  immediately  after  TA 
approval. The main duty of these two consultants is to develop the initial gas sector policy 
agenda that will eventually form the basis for the proposed sector development program. 
 
1.  Gas Sector Development Policy Specialist (International, 3 person-months) 
(i)  Evaluate  the  progress  of  the  Gas  Sector  Reform  Roadmap  and  other  policy 
developments in the country with respect to overall gas sector development. 
 
(ii)  Suggest a policy agenda and action plan that would assure sufficient gas would be 
discovered and brought to market through market mechanisms.  
 
(iii)  Develop a policy agenda for reduction of system losses in the gas sector, taking into 
account  ADB’s  recent  interventions  such  as  the  Gas  Transmission  and 
Development Project.8 
 
(iv)  Prepare a detailed policy matrix incorporating all of the above with adequate details, 
which is to be included in the ensuing Gas Sector Development Program.

(i)  Assist the international gas sector development policy specialist assess and develop 
a mechanism to ensure a sufficient amount of gas is discovered, developed, and 
brought to market.

III.   Individual Consultants’ Terms of Reference 
 
Two consultants will be recruited as individual consultants by ADB, according to its Guidelines. 
The work will be commenced after approval and completed at the early part of the stage II of 
the TA. The main purpose of these two consultants is to develop the initial gas sector policy 
agenda that eventually form the basis for the proposed sector development program. 
 
A.  Gas Sector Development Policy Specialist (International, 3pm) 
(i)  Assess the information base on amount of gas discovered, developed, brought to  
market and their relevance to gas pricing system in Bangladesh;  
 
(ii)  Evaluate  the  progress  of  the  Gas  Sector  Reform  Roadmap  and  other  policy 
developments in the country with respect to overall gas sector development; 
 
(iii)  Suggest a policy agenda and action plan that would assure sufficient gas would be 
discovered and brought to market through market mechanisms;  
 
(iv)  Review the present foundation for gas pricing consistent with the market based 
approach, taking into account the best practice examples available internationally, 
and recommend a gas pricing policy for the county;  
 
(v)  Assess the relationship between gas and power sector activities and propose a 
required gas sector policy agenda for sustainability of the two sectors;

22  
 
(vi)  Propose a stepwise procedure for empowerment of energy regulators to make and 
endorse independent decisions on gas pricing; 
 
(vii)  Develop a policy agenda for system loss reduction in the gas sector taking into 
account  ADB’s  recent  interventions  such  the  Gas  Sector  Transmission  and 
Development Project; 
 
(viii)  Propose an institutional mechanism to assure items studied in the TOR; and 
 
(ix)  Prepare a detailed Policy Matrix incorporating all of the above with adequate details 
to be included in the ensuing Gas Sector Development Program. 
 
B.  Gas Sector Development Specialist (National, 3pm) 
(i)  Assist  international  Gas  Sector  Development  Policy  Specialist  to  assess  and 
develop  a  mechanism  for  sufficient  amount  of  gas  discovered,  developed,  and 
brought to market;  
 
(ii)  Provide details on past and present gas pricing system and substitute fuel prices;  
 
(iii)  Work with the international Gas Sector Development Policy Specialist in developing 
system loss reduction plan and milestone setting;  
 
(iv)  Support international consultants in understanding the coordination between gas 
and power sector activities, and   
 
(v)  Work  with  international  consultants  empowering  the  energy  regulators  to  make 
independent decisions.
